intro: Myrsine mexicana, commonly known as Mexican myrsine, is a shrub native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant typically grows to a height of 1 to 2 meters, featuring opposite, oval-shaped leaves with a smooth or slightly hairy surface. Its small, white to pinkish flowers are clustered in inflorescences, and it produces small, dark purple berries as fruit. The leaves and stems are often used in traditional medicine for their purported healing properties.
